CONCEPT.name: Childhood vs. Adulthood
CONCEPT.description: The narrative contrasts the perspectives of children, who possess imagination and a capacity for wonder, with those of adults, who are often preoccupied with practical matters and lack the ability to see beyond the surface. The story suggests that adults have lost touch with the essential things in life, while children retain a connection to them.

CONCEPT.name: Imagination and Creativity
CONCEPT.description: The story emphasizes the importance of imagination and creativity, particularly in the context of art and understanding. The narrator's early attempts at drawing are dismissed by adults, highlighting how societal pressures can stifle creativity. The little prince, in contrast, embraces imagination, seeing beyond the literal and finding meaning in the unseen.

CONCEPT.name: Love and Responsibility
CONCEPT.description: The concept of love is central to the story, particularly in the context of the little prince's relationship with his rose. The story explores the idea that love involves responsibility, care, and a deep understanding of the beloved. The little prince's journey is, in part, a quest to understand the nature of love and his responsibility for the rose.

CONCEPT.name: Loss and Grief
CONCEPT.description: The story deals with themes of loss and grief, both in the context of the narrator's experiences and the little prince's. The narrator mourns the loss of his friend, while the little prince experiences sadness over his rose and his separation from his planet. The story suggests that grief is a natural part of life and that it can lead to a deeper understanding of the world.

CONCEPT.name: The Importance of the Heart
CONCEPT.description: The story emphasizes the importance of looking with the heart, rather than just the eyes. The fox's secret, "What is essential is invisible to the eye," underscores the idea that true understanding and connection come from emotional and spiritual awareness. This concept is contrasted with the superficiality of the adult world, which often values material possessions and external appearances.

CONCEPT.name: Taming and Friendship
CONCEPT.description: The concept of "taming" is central to the story, representing the process of forming meaningful relationships. The fox explains that taming involves establishing ties and becoming unique to each other. This process requires time, patience, and a willingness to be vulnerable. The story suggests that friendship is a valuable and essential part of life.

CONCEPT.name: The Search for Meaning
CONCEPT.description: The little prince's journey is a quest for meaning and understanding. He travels to different planets, encountering various characters who represent different aspects of human nature. Through these encounters, he learns about the complexities of life, the importance of love, and the value of human connection. The story suggests that the search for meaning is a lifelong journey.

CONCEPT.name: The Nature of Reality
CONCEPT.description: The story explores the nature of reality, suggesting that there is more to the world than what is immediately apparent. The little prince's ability to see beyond the surface, his connection to his rose, and his understanding of the stars all point to a deeper, more meaningful reality. The story encourages readers to question their assumptions and to look for the unseen.

CONCEPT.name: Responsibility and Duty
CONCEPT.description: The little prince's sense of responsibility for his rose and the narrator's responsibility for the little prince highlight the importance of duty and care. The story suggests that we are responsible for the things we love and that we must take care of them. This concept is contrasted with the selfishness and indifference of some of the adult characters.

CONCEPT.name: The Value of Simplicity
CONCEPT.description: The story contrasts the simplicity of the little prince's life with the complexities of the adult world. The little prince values the simple things, such as his rose, his sheep, and the sunsets. The story suggests that true happiness and fulfillment can be found in simplicity and in appreciating the beauty of the world around us.

LOCATION.name: Lyon, France
LOCATION.description: Lyon is the birthplace of Antoine de Saint-Exupéry. It is where he was born on June 29, 1900. The city is mentioned in the biography of the author.
LOCATION.significance: Birthplace of the author.

LOCATION.name: France
LOCATION.description: France is mentioned as the place where Leon Werth lives. It is also where the narrator imagines the little prince's friend, Leon Werth, is hungry and cold.
LOCATION.significance: Place where Leon Werth lives.

LOCATION.name: United States
LOCATION.description: The United States is where Saint-Exupéry escaped to after the Germans occupied France. The narrator mentions that when it is noon in the United States, the sun is setting over France.
LOCATION.significance: Place where Saint-Exupéry wrote 'The Little Prince'.

LOCATION.name: North Africa
LOCATION.description: North Africa is where Saint-Exupéry rejoined the air force in 1943. It is mentioned in the biography of the author.
LOCATION.significance: Location of Saint-Exupéry's military service.

LOCATION.name: Mediterranean Sea
LOCATION.description: The Mediterranean Sea is where Saint-Exupéry died when his plane was shot down. It is mentioned in the biography of the author.
LOCATION.significance: Location of Saint-Exupéry's death.

LOCATION.name: Desert of Sahara
LOCATION.description: The Desert of Sahara is where the narrator crashes his plane and meets the little prince. It is a vast and isolated place.
LOCATION.significance: Primary setting where the narrator and the little prince meet and interact.

LOCATION.name: Ocean
LOCATION.description: The ocean is mentioned as a point of comparison for the narrator's isolation in the desert.
LOCATION.significance: Used to emphasize the narrator's isolation.

LOCATION.name: China
LOCATION.description: China is mentioned as a place the narrator can distinguish from Arizona.
LOCATION.significance: Used to illustrate the narrator's geographical knowledge.

LOCATION.name: Arizona
LOCATION.description: Arizona is mentioned as a place the narrator can distinguish from China.
LOCATION.significance: Used to illustrate the narrator's geographical knowledge.

LOCATION.name: Asteroid B-612
LOCATION.description: Asteroid B-612 is the planet from which the little prince came. It is described as being scarcely any larger than a house.
LOCATION.significance: The little prince's home planet.

LOCATION.name: Earth
LOCATION.description: The Earth is the seventh planet visited by the little prince. It is described as having many inhabitants and various locations.
LOCATION.significance: The planet where the little prince meets the narrator and has many adventures.

LOCATION.name: New Zealand
LOCATION.description: New Zealand is mentioned in the context of lamplighters on Earth.
LOCATION.significance: Used to illustrate the size of the Earth.

LOCATION.name: Australia
LOCATION.description: Australia is mentioned in the context of lamplighters on Earth.
LOCATION.significance: Used to illustrate the size of the Earth.

LOCATION.description: Siberia is mentioned in the context of lamplighters on Earth.
LOCATION.significance: Used to illustrate the size of the Earth.

LOCATION.significance: Used to illustrate the size of the Earth.

LOCATION.description: The Indies are mentioned in the context of lamplighters on Earth.
LOCATION.significance: Used to illustrate the size of the Earth.

LOCATION.description: Africa is mentioned as the place where the snake says the little prince is.
LOCATION.significance: Location where the little prince meets the snake.

LOCATION.name: Garden
LOCATION.description: The little prince discovers a garden of roses that look like his own rose.
LOCATION.significance: The little prince realizes his rose is unique.

LOCATION.name: Wheat fields
LOCATION.description: The fox says that the wheat fields will remind him of the little prince.

LOCATION.name: Village
LOCATION.description: The well that the little prince and the narrator find is like a well in a village.

TIME_PERIOD.description: Antoine de Saint-Exupéry's lifespan, including his birth in 1900 and death in 1944.

TIME_PERIOD.name: 1920s

TIME_PERIOD.name: World War II
TIME_PERIOD.description: Saint-Exupéry flew as a military reconnaissance pilot during this time.

TIME_PERIOD.name: July 31, 1944
TIME_PERIOD.description: Saint-Exupéry died when his plane was shot down during a reconnaissance mission.
Saint-Exupery's first book, 'Southern Mail', was published in French.
The book 'Wind, Sand, and Stars' was published.
The Little Prince was written during Saint-Exupery's stay in the United States.
The book 'The Wisdom of the Sands' was published after the pilot's death.

EVENT.summary: The ebook's purpose and usage are announced.

EVENT.name: Author's Biography
EVENT.summary: A brief biography of Antoine de Saint-Exupéry is provided.

EVENT.name: Chapter 1: Introduction to the Narrator and Grown-ups
EVENT.summary: The narrator, a pilot, shares his childhood experiences and opinions about grown-ups.

EVENT.name: Chapter 2: Crash Landing and Meeting the Little Prince
EVENT.summary: The narrator crashes in the desert and meets the little prince, who asks him to draw a sheep.

EVENT.name: Chapter 3: Learning About the Little Prince's Origins
EVENT.summary: The narrator learns that the little prince comes from another planet and asks about his home.

EVENT.name: Chapter 4: Speculation on Asteroid B-612
EVENT.summary: The narrator speculates that the little prince comes from Asteroid B-612 and discusses the grown-ups' focus on figures.

EVENT.name: Chapter 5: The Baobabs
EVENT.summary: The little prince warns about the dangers of baobabs and the importance of discipline.

EVENT.name: Chapter 6: Sunsets
EVENT.summary: The little prince and the narrator discuss sunsets and the little prince's fondness for them.

EVENT.name: Chapter 7: The Secret of the Little Prince's Life
EVENT.summary: The narrator learns about the little prince's love for a unique rose and the importance of understanding.

EVENT.name: Chapter 8: The Rose's Arrival
EVENT.summary: The story of the rose's arrival on the little prince's planet and her vanity is revealed.

EVENT.name: Chapter 9: The Little Prince's Departure
EVENT.summary: The little prince decides to leave his planet and says goodbye to his rose.

EVENT.name: Chapter 10: The King
EVENT.summary: The little prince visits a king who rules over everything but cannot control the sun.

EVENT.name: Chapter 11: The Conceited Man
EVENT.summary: The little prince visits a conceited man who wants to be admired.

EVENT.name: Chapter 12: The Tippler
EVENT.summary: The little prince visits a tippler who drinks to forget his shame.

EVENT.name: Chapter 13: The Businessman
EVENT.summary: The little prince visits a businessman who owns stars and is obsessed with numbers.

EVENT.name: Chapter 14: The Lamplighter
EVENT.summary: The little prince visits a lamplighter who works tirelessly, and the little prince finds him admirable.

EVENT.name: Chapter 15: The Geographer
EVENT.summary: The little prince visits a geographer who does not explore and learns about ephemeral things.

EVENT.name: Chapter 16: The Earth
EVENT.summary: The narrator discusses the Earth and its inhabitants, including the lamplighters.

EVENT.name: Chapter 17: The Snake
EVENT.summary: The little prince meets a snake in the desert who offers to help him return to his planet.

EVENT.name: Chapter 18: The Flower
EVENT.summary: The little prince meets a flower in the desert who tells him about the men.

EVENT.name: Chapter 19: The Echo
EVENT.summary: The little prince climbs a mountain and encounters an echo.

EVENT.name: Chapter 20: The Rose Garden
EVENT.summary: The little prince discovers a garden of roses that look like his own, leading to sadness.

EVENT.name: Chapter 21: The Fox
EVENT.summary: The little prince befriends a fox who teaches him about the importance of taming and establishing ties.

EVENT.name: Chapter 22: The Switchman
EVENT.summary: The little prince encounters a railway switchman who sorts travelers.

EVENT.name: Chapter 23: The Merchant
EVENT.summary: The little prince meets a merchant who sells pills to quench thirst.

EVENT.name: Chapter 24: The Search for Water
EVENT.summary: The narrator and the little prince search for a well in the desert.

EVENT.name: Chapter 25: Finding the Well
EVENT.summary: The narrator and the little prince find a well and discuss the little prince's return to his planet.

EVENT.name: Chapter 26: The Little Prince's Return
EVENT.summary: The little prince meets the snake, and the narrator witnesses his return to his planet.

EVENT.name: Chapter 27: Afterthoughts
EVENT.summary: The narrator reflects on the little prince's departure and the mystery of the rose and the sheep.

CHAPTER.title: Chapter 1
CHAPTER.summary: The narrator, a pilot, recounts his childhood experiences with drawing and his disillusionment with grown-ups. He shares his Drawing Number One and Drawing Number Two, which were not understood by adults. He then describes his life as a pilot and his encounters with grown-ups, who fail to understand essential matters.

CHAPTER.title: Chapter 2
CHAPTER.summary: The narrator crashes in the Sahara Desert and meets the little prince, who asks him to draw a sheep. The narrator struggles with the drawing, eventually drawing a box with a sheep inside. The little prince is pleased with the drawing and reveals that he comes from a very small planet.

CHAPTER.title: Chapter 3
CHAPTER.summary: The narrator learns more about the little prince's origins through their conversations. The little prince reveals that he comes from another planet and shows a fondness for his sheep. The narrator's curiosity is piqued, and he tries to learn more about the little prince's home.

CHAPTER.title: Chapter 4
CHAPTER.summary: The narrator speculates about the little prince's planet, Asteroid B-612, and discusses the importance of understanding essential matters rather than focusing on superficial details. He explains how grown-ups often prioritize figures and numbers over genuine connections and experiences.

CHAPTER.title: Chapter 5
CHAPTER.summary: The narrator learns about the dangers of baobab trees on the little prince's planet. The little prince explains the importance of vigilance and discipline in preventing the baobabs from taking over a planet. The narrator draws a picture of the planet to warn children about the baobabs.

CHAPTER.title: Chapter 6
CHAPTER.summary: The little prince shares his love for sunsets and explains how he can watch them whenever he wants on his small planet. He reveals that he once saw forty-four sunsets in a single day and that he loves sunsets when he is sad.

CHAPTER.title: Chapter 7
CHAPTER.summary: The narrator learns about the secret of the little prince's life, which involves a rose. The little prince explains the importance of the rose and the thorns, and he becomes upset when the narrator dismisses the thorns as useless. The little prince reveals his love for the rose and his concern for her safety.

CHAPTER.title: Chapter 8
CHAPTER.summary: The narrator learns more about the rose, which arrived on the little prince's planet from a seed. The rose is described as vain and demanding, and the little prince struggles to understand her. The little prince realizes that he should have judged the rose by her actions rather than her words.

CHAPTER.title: Chapter 9
CHAPTER.summary: The little prince prepares to leave his planet, taking advantage of a flock of migrating birds. He cleans his volcanoes and says goodbye to the rose. The rose expresses her love for him and encourages him to be happy.

CHAPTER.title: Chapter 10
CHAPTER.summary: The little prince visits a king on an asteroid. The king claims to rule over everything but has no subjects to command. The little prince learns about the king's authority and asks for a sunset, which the king grants, but only at a specific time.

CHAPTER.title: Chapter 11
CHAPTER.summary: The little prince visits a conceited man on another asteroid. The conceited man wants to be admired but has no one to admire him. The little prince finds the conceited man's behavior odd and continues his journey.

CHAPTER.title: Chapter 12
CHAPTER.summary: The little prince visits a tippler on another asteroid. The tippler drinks to forget that he is ashamed of drinking. The little prince is saddened by the tippler's behavior and continues his journey.

CHAPTER.title: Chapter 13
CHAPTER.summary: The little prince visits a businessman on another asteroid. The businessman is obsessed with counting and owning stars. The little prince questions the value of owning stars and finds the businessman's actions meaningless.

CHAPTER.title: Chapter 14
CHAPTER.summary: The little prince visits a lamplighter on another asteroid. The lamplighter's job is to light and extinguish a street lamp every minute. The little prince admires the lamplighter's dedication and finds his work meaningful, unlike the other grown-ups he has met.

CHAPTER.title: Chapter 15
CHAPTER.summary: The little prince visits a geographer on another planet. The geographer is a scholar who knows the locations of geographical features but does not explore. The geographer advises the little prince to visit Earth.

CHAPTER.title: Chapter 16
CHAPTER.summary: The narrator discusses the Earth and its inhabitants, including the vast number of grown-ups. He describes the army of lamplighters that existed before electricity and the spectacle they would have created.

CHAPTER.title: Chapter 17
CHAPTER.summary: The little prince arrives on Earth and meets a snake. The snake tells him that he is in the desert and that there are no people. The little prince asks about the stars and the possibility of finding his own star again.

CHAPTER.title: Chapter 18
CHAPTER.summary: The little prince crosses the desert and meets a flower. The flower tells him that there are only six or seven men in existence and that they are blown away by the wind. The little prince says goodbye to the flower.

CHAPTER.title: Chapter 19
CHAPTER.summary: The little prince climbs a mountain and tries to find people. He encounters an echo and realizes that the people have no imagination.

CHAPTER.title: Chapter 19
CHAPTER.summary: The little prince climbs a mountain and tries to find people. He encounters an echo and realizes that the people have no imagination.

CHAPTER.title: Chapter 20
CHAPTER.summary: The little prince discovers a garden of roses that look like his own rose. He realizes that his rose is not unique and feels sad. He reflects on his experience and his relationship with his rose.

CHAPTER.title: Chapter 21
CHAPTER.summary: The little prince befriends a fox. The fox explains the meaning of 'tame' and the importance of establishing ties. The little prince learns that his rose is unique because he has tamed her. The fox shares his secret: 'It is only with the heart that one can see rightly; what is essential is invisible to the eye.'

CHAPTER.title: Chapter 22
CHAPTER.summary: The little prince encounters a railway switchman. The switchman sorts travelers and sends them on trains. The little prince observes that the travelers are always in a hurry and never satisfied.

CHAPTER.title: Chapter 23
CHAPTER.summary: The little prince encounters a merchant who sells pills that quench thirst. The little prince questions the value of the pills and prefers to walk towards a spring of fresh water.

CHAPTER.title: Chapter 24
CHAPTER.summary: The narrator and the little prince, both thirsty, search for a well in the desert. They discuss the beauty of the desert and the importance of what is invisible. They find a well, and the little prince drinks the water.

CHAPTER.title: Chapter 25
CHAPTER.summary: The little prince and the narrator discuss the little prince's return to his planet. The little prince asks the narrator to draw a muzzle for his sheep. The little prince reveals that the anniversary of his arrival on Earth is approaching.

CHAPTER.title: Chapter 26
CHAPTER.summary: The little prince meets the snake and prepares to return to his planet. The narrator witnesses the little prince's encounter with the snake and is deeply saddened. The little prince explains that he must return to his planet and that his body will be left behind. He shares his secret about the stars and the importance of what is essential. The little prince is bitten by the snake and returns to his planet.

CHAPTER.title: Chapter 27
CHAPTER.summary: The narrator reflects on the little prince's departure and the mystery surrounding it. He wonders if the sheep ate the rose and acknowledges the importance of the little prince's story. The narrator encourages the reader to consider the mystery and to look up at the sky, asking themselves if the sheep ate the rose.

Emotional_TRUSTS.source: Dedication of the book to Leon Werth, calling him the best friend in the world.
The narrator trusts the little prince enough to share his water and help him.
The little prince trusts the narrator enough to share his story and ask for help.
The little prince trusts the fox enough to be tamed by him.
The fox trusts the little prince enough to be tamed by him.
The little prince trusts the snake enough to let it bite him.

Emotional_BETRAYED.motive: The narrator's inability to understand the little prince's perspective and the little prince's eventual departure.
The rose's vanity and demanding nature led the little prince to doubt her and leave his planet.
The snake's role in the little prince's return to his planet, which involved a fatal bite.

Concept_BELIEVES_IN.manifestation: The narrator reflects on how grown-ups fail to understand the world as children do.
The narrator expresses how he gave up his dream of being a painter because grown-ups did not understand his drawings.
The little prince asks the narrator to draw a sheep, showing his belief in the power of imagination.
The narrator draws the sheep, showing his willingness to engage with the little prince's imaginative world.
The little prince's questions about the narrator's plane and his origin reveal his curiosity about the nature of reality.
The little prince's questions about the sheep and the box reveal his search for meaning in the world.
The narrator reflects on how grown-ups are only interested in figures and numbers, not in the essential things in life.
The little prince is concerned about the baobabs and their potential to destroy his planet, showing his belief in the importance of taking care of one's environment.
The little prince explains the importance of pulling up baobabs, showing his belief in the importance of responsibility.
The little prince loves sunsets and finds comfort in them, showing his belief in the importance of finding beauty and meaning in life.
The little prince is upset that the flower's thorns are of no use, showing his belief in the importance of love and the value of things.
The little prince is upset about the flower and the sheep, showing his belief in the importance of love and responsibility.

The little prince cares for his rose, showing his belief in the importance of love and responsibility.
The little prince is hurt by the rose's vanity, showing his belief in the importance of love and responsibility.
The little prince prepares to leave his planet, showing his belief in the importance of responsibility and the need to move on.

The little prince understands that his rose is unique because of the time he spent with her, showing his belief in the importance of love and responsibility.
The little prince learns the fox's secret: what is essential is invisible to the eye, showing his belief in the importance of the heart.
The little prince understands that he is responsible for his rose, showing his belief in the importance of love and responsibility.
